4. **Control Structures (Selection):** Post-midterm content (Weeks 10-11) covers Conditional Statements, specifically implementation of selection control structures like If, If-Else, If-Then, Else-if, and compound statements.

5. **Control Structures (Iteration):** Weeks 12-13 cover Looping constructs, differentiating between For loops, While loops, and Do-While loops.

6. **Advanced Constructs:** The final portion of the semester covers Case and Functions (Week 14), Arrays (Week 15), and Strings (Week 16). The course concludes with an introduction to Advance C concepts in Week 17.

Grading for this course is weighted as follows: Performance Tasks (Quizzes, Projects, Research Papers) account for 50%, Written Work (Homework, Problem Sets) accounts for 25%, and Term Assessments (Midterm/Final Exam) account for 25%. 

**Note:** While the provided source document contains erroneous learning outcomes regarding Calculus (limits/derivatives), the actual course content, mapping grid, and references explicitly focus on Computer Programming and C-Language fundamentals.

source: OBTL Plan - Computer Programming 1 (Fundamentals of Programming) (Lecture)
topic: FPROGLEC: Computer Programming 1 (Fundamentals of Programming) (Lecture)
content:
FPROGLEC - Computer Programming 1 (Fundamentals of Programming) (Lecture) is a course designed to train students in using a general-purpose programming language to design, implement, test, and debug programs. The source document lists the credit allocation as 1 unit (lab) with 3 contact hours per week, though the course title specifies it as a Lecture component. It has no prerequisites and serves as a prerequisite for IPROGLEC .

**Course Content & Weekly Plan:**
The curriculum progresses from logic formulation to advanced C-language constructs:
* **Fundamentals (Weeks 2-3):** Covers Flowcharting (definitions and uses) and Algorithms (explanation and application) .
* **Introduction to C (Weeks 4-5):** Explores the history, objectives, characteristics, and components of C-Language, including reserved words, preprocessors, and organization .
* **Basic Structure (Weeks 6-8):** Focuses on creating simple programs, understanding C-Language structure, variable declaration, and using local/global variables .
* **Control Structures (Weeks 10-13):** Covers Conditional Statements (If, If-Else, If-Then, Else-if) and Looping constructs (For, While, Do-While) .
* **Advanced Topics (Weeks 14-17):** Introduces Case & Functions, Arrays, Strings, and an Introduction to Advance C concepts .

**Assessment & Resources:**
Grading is divided into Performance Tasks (50%), Written Work (25%), and Term Assessments (25%). Recommended text resources include "Starting Out with C++: From Control Structures through Objects" and "C Programming: A Modern Approach".

*(Note: The source document contains a clerical error listing Calculus learning outcomes (limits, derivatives) in the Outcomes section; this summary relies on the Course Description, Mapping Grid, and Weekly Plan which correctly describe a Computer Programming course.)*

topic: INTCOMLB: Introduction to Computing (Laboratory)
content:
INTCOMLB - Introduction to Computing (Laboratory) is a 3-unit laboratory course covering broad fundamental concepts in Information Technology. It has no prerequisites and serves as a prerequisite for INFOMGT. Although the official course description in the syllabus generically mentions 'general purpose programming,' the detailed weekly plan outlines a curriculum focused on the foundational pillars of computing rather than deep programming implementation.

**Course Content & Weekly Plan:**
* **Foundations (Weeks 1-3):** Covers the history and evolution of computing, the computing profession, and Number Systems.
* **System Components (Weeks 4-5):** detailed study of Computer Systems, Operating Systems, Hardware/Software components, and an introduction to Malware/Viruses.
* **Connectivity & Security (Weeks 6-7):** Focuses on Computer Security (Hacking, Phishing, Privacy Acts) and Internet fundamentals (Protocols, WWW, Cyberspace).
* **Web Development (Weeks 8-9):** Introduction to HTML and CSS for website structure and design.
* **Systems Concepts (Week 10-12):** Covers Computer Organization and Architecture, Global Information Systems, and the System Development Life Cycle (SDLC).
* **Enterprise & Support Systems (Weeks 13-14):** Explores Enterprise Systems (SCM, CRM, ERP) and Management Support Systems (DSS, ESS).
* **Advanced Topics (Weeks 15-17):** Introduces Intelligent Information Systems (Artificial Intelligence, Expert Systems, Neural Networks) and emerging trends like Virtual Reality, RFID, and Nanotechnology.

**Assessment:**
The course grading is heavily weighted towards Performance Tasks (50%), followed by Written Work (25%) and Term Assessments (25%).

topic: INTCOMLC: Introduction to Computing (Lecture)
content:
INTCOMLC - Introduction to Computing (Lecture) is a 3-unit course designed to provide a comprehensive overview of the Information Technology field. It has no prerequisites and is a prerequisite for INFOMGT. While the official course description and learning outcomes in the source document contain clerical errors (referencing programming and calculus), the detailed teaching plan outlines a curriculum focused on IT fundamentals rather than pure programming or mathematics.

**Course Content & Weekly Plan:**
* **IT Foundations (Weeks 1-3):** Covers the history and evolution of computing, the computing profession, and Number Systems .
* **System Architecture (Weeks 4-5):** Examines key components of computer systems, Operating Systems, Hardware/Software definitions, and introduces concepts of Malware and Viruses .
* **Connectivity & Security (Weeks 6-7):** Focuses on Computer Security (Hacking, Phishing, Privacy Acts) and Internet fundamentals (Protocols, WWW, Cyberspace) .
* **Web Technologies (Weeks 8-9):** Introduces HTML and CSS for website structure and design .
* **Systems Concepts (Weeks 10-12):** Covers Computer Organization and Architecture, Global Information Systems, and the System Development Life Cycle (SDLC) .
* **Enterprise Applications (Weeks 13-14):** Explores Enterprise Systems (Supply Chain Management, CRM, ERP) and Management Support Systems (Decision Support, Executive Information Systems) .
* **Advanced Topics (Weeks 15-17):** Introduces Intelligent Information Systems (Artificial Intelligence, Expert Systems, Neural Networks) and emerging trends such as Virtual Reality, RFID, and Nanotechnology .

**Assessment & Resources:**
Grading is weighted towards Performance Tasks (50%), followed by Written Work (25%) and Term Assessments (25%). The primary text reference is "Hands on Virtual Computing" by Simpson.

source: OBTL Plan - Data Structure and Algorithm (Laboratory)
topic: DSALGLAB: Data Structure and Algorithm (Laboratory)
content:
DSALGLAB - Data Structure and Algorithm (Laboratory) is a course with a credit value of 2 units (lecture) and 2 contact hours per week, according to the document. It serves as a prerequisite to MICROBOT and requires IPROGLAB as a prerequisite. The course covers abstract data types (ADTs) and the implementation of fundamental data structures, including arrays, stacks, queues, linked lists, and mapping trees. It also covers internal and external searching and sorting algorithms and dynamic storage management .

**Weekly Content Plan:**
* **Fundamentals (Week 2):** Introduction to Data Structures, Algorithms, and Abstract Data Types .
* **Arrays (Weeks 3-4):** Covers Linear Arrays, Multi-Dimensional Arrays, Dynamic Arrays, and operations on arrays .
* **Linked Lists (Weeks 5-6):** Implementation of Singly Linked Lists, Doubly Linked Lists, and Circular Linked Lists .
* **Recursion (Weeks 7-8):** Focuses on recursive definitions, writing recursive programs, simulating recursion, and analyzing efficiency .
* **Stacks and Queues (Weeks 10-12):** Covers Stack representation and operations , followed by Queue representation and operations .
* **Trees (Weeks 13-14):** topics include Binary Trees, Tree Representation, Expression Trees, and Tree Traversal applications .
* **Sorting (Weeks 15-16):** Covers various sorting algorithms including Exchange, Selection, Tree, Insertion, Merge, and Radix sorts .
* **Graphs (Week 17):** Introduces Directed and Undirected Graphs, Graph Representations, Search Algorithms, Shortest Path Problems, and Spanning Trees .

**Tools and Resources:**
The reference materials suggest the use of **C++** as the primary programming language for implementation. Assessment is based on Performance Tasks (50%), Written Work (25%), and Term Assessments (25%).

source: OBTL Plan - Data Structure and Algorithm (Lecture)
topic: DSALGLEC: Data Structure and Algorithm (Lecture)
content:
DSALGLEC - Data Structure and Algorithm (Lecture) is a 2-unit lecture course designed to introduce students to abstract data types and the implementation of fundamental data structures. The course requires IPROGLEC as a prerequisite and serves as a prerequisite for MICROBOT. The curriculum covers the design and implementation of data structures such as arrays, stacks, queues, linked lists, and mapping trees, alongside internal and external searching and sorting algorithms and dynamic storage management. 

**Weekly Course Outline:**
* **Foundations (Week 2):** Introduction to Data Structures, Algorithms, and Abstract Data Types (ADTs) .
* **Linear Structures (Weeks 3-6):** Detailed study of Arrays (linear, multi-dimensional, dynamic) and Operations on Arrays, followed by Linked Lists (singly, doubly, and circular) .
* **Recursion (Weeks 7-8):** Covers recursive definitions, processes, writing recursive programs, simulating recursion, and analyzing efficiency .
* **Stack and Queue ADTs (Weeks 10-12):** Focuses on the representation and operations of Stacks and Queues .
* **Hierarchical Structures (Weeks 13-14):** Introduction to Trees, specifically Binary Trees, their representation, traversals, and applications such as Expression Trees .
* **Sorting Algorithms (Weeks 15-16):** Examination of various sorting methods including Exchange, Selection, Tree, Insertion, Merge, and Radix sorts .
* **Graphs (Week 17):** Covers Directed and Undirected Graphs, Graph Representations, Search Algorithms, Shortest Path Problems, and Spanning Trees .

**Assessment and Resources:**
Grading is calculated based on Written Work (25%), Performance Tasks (45%), and Term Assessments (30%). Recommended learning resources indicate the use of C++ as the primary programming language for demonstrating these concepts.

topic: DISCMATH: Discrete Mathematics
content:
DISCMATH - Discrete Mathematics is a 3-unit lecture course covering the fundamental mathematical structures and logic essential for computer science. It has no prerequisites. 

**Course Content & Weekly Plan:**
Although some sections of the source document contain clerical errors referencing programming descriptions or calculus outcomes, the detailed **Teaching and Learning Plan** confirms the specific curriculum as follows:
* **Sets and Logic (Weeks 2-4, 7-8):** Covers Set Theory (definitions, operations), Induction (strong induction), and Mathematical Logic (propositions, predicates, quantifiers, negations, logical connectives, tautologies, and inference).
* **Proof Techniques & Number Theory (Weeks 4-6):** Includes direct proofs, proofs by contradiction, Divisibility (division algorithm, GCD), Prime Numbers (Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic), and Modular Arithmetic (congruence).
* **Relations and Functions (Week 7):** Differentiates between relations and functions, covering ordered pairs and types of relations.
* **Counting Principles (Weeks 9-12):** Post-midterm topics include Fundamental Counting Principles, Binomial Coefficients, the Binomial Theorem, the Inclusion-Exclusion Principle, Derangements, and the Pigeonhole Principle.
* **Algorithms and Complexity (Weeks 13-14):** Introduces Asymptotic Notation (Big O) and properties for analyzing algorithm time complexity.
* **Graph Theory and Trees (Weeks 14-17):** Extensive coverage of Graphs (common types, Eulerian, Bipartite, Colored, Planar graphs, Euler's formula) and Trees (basic properties, spanning trees).

**Assessment:**
Grading is weighted as follows: Performance Tasks (45%), Written Work (25%), and Term Assessments (30%).

topic: DISCSTRU: Discrete Structure 1
content:
DISCSTRU - Discrete Structure 1 is a 3-unit lecture course that provides a foundation in the mathematical structures used in computer science. It has no prerequisites. Although the provided syllabus document contains clerical errors in the 'Course Description' and 'Learning Outcomes' sections (incorrectly listing programming and calculus topics), the detailed **Teaching and Learning Plan** outlines a rigorous curriculum in Discrete Mathematics .

**Weekly Course Content:**
* **Sets and Induction (Weeks 2-4):** Covers Set Theory (notation, operations), and Mathematical Induction (including strong induction) .
* **Number Theory & Proofs (Weeks 5-6):** Topics include Direct Proofs, Proof by Contradiction, Divisibility, the Division Algorithm, Greatest Common Divisors (GCD), Prime Numbers, the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic, and Modular Arithmetic .
* **Logic, Relations, & Functions (Weeks 7-8):** Covers Relations (ordered pairs, kinds of relations), Functions, and Mathematical Logic (propositions, predicates, quantifiers, logical connectives, and tautologies) .
* **Combinatorics (Weeks 10-12):** Post-midterm content focuses on Counting Principles, Binomial Coefficients, the Binomial Theorem, and the Inclusion-Exclusion Principle .
* **Asymptotic Analysis (Weeks 13-14):** Introduces Asymptotic Notation for analyzing algorithm time complexity .
* **Graph Theory (Weeks 13-17):** Extensive coverage of Graphs (common types, Eulerian, Bipartite, Colored), Trees (spanning trees), and Planar Graphs (Euler's formula, coloring) .

**Assessment:**
The course grading is weighted as follows: Performance Tasks (45%), Written Work (25%), and Term Assessments (30%).

topic: IPROGLAB: Computer Programming 2 (Intermediate Programming) (Laboratory)
content:
IPROGLAB - Computer Programming 2 (Intermediate Programming) (Laboratory) is a 1-unit laboratory course with 3 contact hours per week. It requires FPROGLAB as a prerequisite and serves as a prerequisite for DSALGLAB. The course utilizes C++ to train students in designing, implementing, testing, and debugging programs using intermediate programming constructs .

**Weekly Course Content:**
* **Fundamentals & Operators (Weeks 2-4):** Covers C++ elements (reserved words, constants, basic types) and various operators (arithmetic, logical, relational, bitwise, assignment, increment/decrement) .
* **Control Structures (Weeks 5-6):** Implementation of control flow including compound statements, conditional statements (If, If-else, Switch), and iteration constructs (For, While, Do-while loops) .
* **Modular Programming (Weeks 7-8):** Focuses on C++ Functions, including structure, prototyping, return data types, parameters, and function overloading .
* **Memory Management & Strings (Weeks 10-12):** Detailed study of Pointers (declaring, reference/dereference operators, null pointers, pointers to pointers/functions) and String manipulation (declaration, initialization, functions) .
* **Data Structures & Files (Weeks 13-16):** Covers Structures (nesting, pointers to structures) and File handling (File class, streams, reading/writing records, random access files) .
* **Object-Oriented Concepts (Weeks 17-18):** Introduces principles of Object-Oriented Programming including Classes (private/public sections), Encapsulation, Real Objects, Constructors, and Destructors .

**Assessment:**
Grading is weighted as follows: Performance Tasks (45%), Term Assessments (30%), and Written Work (25%) .

*(Note: The source document contains a clerical error listing Calculus learning outcomes (limits, derivatives) in the Outcomes section; this summary relies on the Course Description and Weekly Content Plan which correctly describe an Intermediate C++ Programming course.)*

source: OBTL Plan - Computer Programming 2 (Intermediate Programming - Lec)
topic: IPROGLEC: Computer Programming 2 (Intermediate Programming) (Lecture)
content:
IPROGLEC - Computer Programming 2 (Intermediate Programming) (Lecture) is a course designed to train students in designing, implementing, testing, and debugging programs using intermediate constructs of a general-purpose programming language, specifically C++. The syllabus lists the course credit as 1 unit with 3 contact hours per week, identifies **FPROGLAB** as a prerequisite, and notes that it serves as a prerequisite for **DSALGLAB** .

**Weekly Course Content:**
* **Fundamentals (Weeks 1-2):** Orientation and a review of C++ elements including reserved words, constants, and basic data types .
* **Operators and Expressions (Weeks 3-4):** Detailed study of arithmetic, logical, relational, bitwise, assignment, and increment/decrement operators .
* **Control Structures (Weeks 5-6):** Implementation of control flow statements including compound statements, conditional statements (If, If-else, Switch), and iteration (For, While, Do-while loops) .
* **Modular Programming (Weeks 7-8):** Focuses on C++ Functions, covering structure, prototyping, return data types, parameters, and function overloading .
* **Memory Management (Weeks 10-11):** Comprehensive coverage of Pointers, including declaration, reference/dereference operators, null pointers, and pointers to pointers or functions .
* **String Manipulation (Weeks 11-12):** String declaration, initialization, and string functions .
* **Complex Data Types (Weeks 13-14):** Introduction to Structures, nesting structures, and pointers to structures .
* **File Handling (Weeks 15-16):** Using File classes and streams, reading/writing to files, and handling random access files .
* **Object-Oriented Programming (Weeks 17-18):** Introduction to Objects, Class encapsulation (Private/Public sections), Constructors, Destructors, and Class Header files .

**Assessment:**
The grading system is weighted as follows: Performance Tasks (45%), Term Assessments (30%), and Written Work (25%) .

*(Note: The provided source document contains a clerical error listing Calculus learning outcomes in the Outcomes section; this summary relies on the Course Description and Weekly Plan which correctly describe a C++ Programming curriculum.)*

topic: BUSANALY: Business Analytics
content:
BUSANALY - Business Analytics is a 2-unit lecture course designed to introduce students to the field of business intelligence and data analysis. 

**Curriculum Note:**
While the "Course Description" section of the source document erroneously describes operating systems and computer architecture (Platform Technologies) , the **Teaching and Learning Plan** outlines a curriculum strictly focused on Business Analytics, Data Mining, and Business Intelligence .

**Course Content & Weekly Plan:**
* **Foundations (Weeks 1-4):** Covers the history of Business Analytics, Business Intelligence (BI) concepts, Pattern Recognition, Data Processing, Decision Types, and BI Tools/Skills .
* **Data Management (Week 5):** detailed study of Data Warehousing, including design considerations, development approaches, architecture, and ETL (Data Loading) processes .
* **Data Mining Fundamentals (Week 6):** Introduction to Data Mining, data cleaning/preparation, and evaluation of outputs .
* **Predictive Modeling (Weeks 7-8):** Covers Decision Trees (construction and algorithms) and Regression Analysis (Linear vs. Logistic, correlations vs. relationships) .
* **Advanced Analytics (Weeks 10-11):** Introduction to Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) design principles and Cluster Analysis (specifically K-Means Algorithm) .
* **Pattern Discovery (Week 12):** Association Rule Mining and the application of the Apriori Algorithm .
* **Unstructured Data (Week 14):** Text Mining (mining the TDM) and Web Mining (Content, Structure, and Usage mining) .
* **Emerging Technologies (Weeks 14-17):** Exploration of Big Data (landscape, technologies, management) and a Data Modelling Primer (Relational Data Models, Data Management Systems) .

**Assessment:**
Grades are calculated based on Performance Tasks (45%), Term Assessments (30%), and Written Work (25%) .

topic: DSALGLAB: Data Structure Laboratory
content:
DSALGLAB - Data Structure Laboratory is a 1-unit laboratory course characterized by 3 contact hours per week. It requires IPROGLAB as a prerequisite and serves as a prerequisite for MICROBOT. The course emphasizes training students to design, implement, test, and debug programs using fundamental data structures and abstract data types .

**Weekly Course Content:**
* **Arrays (Weeks 1-2):** Implementation of Linear, Multi-dimensional, and Dynamic Arrays, including initialization, declaration, and searching (exact and range matching) .
* **Linked Lists (Weeks 3-4):** Creation and manipulation of Singly, Doubly, and Circular Linked Lists using dynamic storage .
* **Recursion (Weeks 5-6):** Covers recursive definitions, identifying base/general cases, simulating recursion, and analyzing efficiency .
* **Stacks (Weeks 7-8):** Stack representation, operations, and implementation as arrays .
* **Queues (Weeks 10-11):** Declaration, initialization, and operations of Queues .
* **Trees (Weeks 12-13):** Focuses on Binary Trees, tree representation, representing lists as binary trees, and tree traversals (including expression trees) .
* **Sorting (Weeks 14-16):** Implementation of various sorting algorithms including Exchange, Selection, Tree, Insertion, Merge, and Radix Sorts .
* **Graphs (Week 17):** Covers Directed and Undirected Graphs, Graph representations, Search Algorithms, Shortest Path problems, and Spanning Trees .

**Tools and Assessment:**
The course utilizes **C++** as the primary programming language for all laboratory exercises. Assessment is heavily weighted towards Performance Tasks (45%) and Term Assessments (30%), with Written Work accounting for 25%. 

*(Note: The source document contains a clerical error listing Calculus learning outcomes in the text ; this summary follows the correct Data Structures curriculum outlined in the teaching plan.)*

topic: INFOMGMTLB: Information Management Laboratory
content:
INFOMGMTLB - Information Management Laboratory is a 1-unit laboratory course characterized by 3 contact hours per week. It requires INTCOMLB as a prerequisite and serves as a prerequisite for OOPRGLAB. While the source document's official description and learning outcomes contain clerical errors (referencing general programming and calculus) , the detailed Teaching and Learning Plan describes a comprehensive survey of Information Systems concepts and applications.

**Course Content & Weekly Plan:**
* **Foundations (Weeks 1-3):** Covers the overview of Information Systems (IS), Computer and Information Literacy, Transaction Processing, MIS, and the history/components of computer hardware and software .
* **Data Management (Week 4):** Introduction to Database Systems, Data Warehouses, and Data Marts, including DBMS components and trends .
* **Ethics & Security (Weeks 5-6):** Examines Personal, Legal, Ethical, and Organizational issues, privacy concerns, computer crime, and methods for Protecting Information Resources .
* **Connectivity (Weeks 7-8):** Covers Data Communication systems, Network configurations, Wireless concepts, and the infrastructure of the Internet, Intranets, and Extranets (including Web 2.0/3.0) .
* **Business Applications (Week 10-11):** Explores E-commerce (B2C, B2B models) and Global Information Systems .
* **System Development (Week 12):** Detailed study of Building Successful Information Systems using the System Development Life Cycle (SDLC) phases: Planning, Requirements, Design, Implementation, and Maintenance .
* **Enterprise Systems (Week 13):** Covers Supply Chain Management (SCM), Customer Relationship Management (CRM), Knowledge Management, and Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) .
* **Decision Support (Week 14):** Introduction to Management Support Systems, Decision Support Systems (DSS), and Executive Information Systems (EIS) .
* **Intelligent Systems (Week 15):** Overview of Artificial Intelligence, Expert Systems, Fuzzy Logic, Neural Networks, and Natural Language Processing .
* **Emerging Trends (Weeks 16-17):** Discussion of SaaS, Virtual Reality, RFID, Biometrics, and Nanotechnology .

**Assessment:**
The course grading is weighted as follows: Performance Tasks (45%), Term Assessments (30%), and Written Work (25%) .

topic: INFMGTLC: Information Management Lecture
content:
INFMGTLC - Information Management Lecture is a 2-unit lecture course with a duration of 2 contact hours per week. It requires INTCOMLC as a prerequisite and serves as a prerequisite for OOPRGLEC. While the official course description and learning outcomes in the source document contain clerical errors (referencing general programming and calculus), the detailed Teaching and Learning Plan outlines a curriculum focused on the theoretical foundations of Information Systems (IS).

**Course Content & Weekly Plan:**
* **Foundations (Weeks 1-3):** Covers the overview of Information Systems, Computer Literacy, Transaction Processing Systems, and the fundamental components of computers (Hardware, Software, Input/Output).
* **Data Management (Week 4):** Explores Database Systems, Database Management Systems (DBMS), Data Warehouses, and Data Marts.
* **Ethics & Security (Weeks 5-6):** Examines Personal, Legal, Ethical, and Organizational issues in IS, alongside Computer and Network Security threats and safeguards.
* **Connectivity (Weeks 7-8):** Covers Data Communication systems, Network configurations, Wireless concepts, and Internet technologies (Intranets, Extranets, Web 2.0/3.0).
* **Business Applications (Week 10-11):** Detailed study of E-commerce models (B2C, B2B) and Global Information Systems.
* **System Development (Week 12):** Focuses on the System Development Life Cycle (SDLC) phases: Planning, Requirements Gathering, Design, Implementation, and Maintenance.
* **Enterprise Systems (Weeks 13-14):** Covers Supply Chain Management (SCM), Customer Relationship Management (CRM), Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP), and Management Support Systems (DSS, EIS).
* **Advanced Topics (Weeks 15-17):** Introduces Intelligent Information Systems (Artificial Intelligence, Expert Systems, Neural Networks) and Emerging Trends such as SaaS, Virtual Reality, RFID, and Biometrics.

**Assessment:**
The course grading is weighted as follows: Performance Tasks (45%), Term Assessments (30%), and Written Work (25%).

topic: PTECHLEC: Platform Technologies Lecture
content:
PTECHLEC - Platform Technologies Lecture is a 2-unit lecture course with 2 contact hours per week . It requires IPATLEC1 as a prerequisite . The course covers the major components of Platform Technologies, specifically Operating Systems and Computer Architecture/Organization. 

**Course Content & Weekly Plan:**
* **Operating Systems (Weeks 2-4):** Covers the history and types of Operating Systems, the Processor, and RAM .
* **Binary Operations (Weeks 5-8):** Focuses on binary addition and multiplication, Logic Gates & Symbols, and Boolean Algebra .
* **Scheduling Algorithms (Weeks 10-12):** Examines Non-Preemptive (FCFS, SJF, Priority) and Pre-emptive (Shortest Remaining Time First, Round Robin, Multi-Level Queue) algorithms .
* **Assembly Language (Week 13):** Introduces basic assembly language variables, operations, and control flows .
* **Computer Organization (Weeks 14-15):** Discusses Enterprise Software, Middleware, Frameworks, and Enterprise Management Software configuration .
* **Firmware and Hardware (Weeks 16-17):** Covers firmware storage options, versioning, digital logic, digital systems, benchmarking, and serial vs. parallel processing .

**Assessment:**
The grading system is weighted as follows: Performance Tasks (45%), Term Assessments (30%), and Written Work (25%).

topic: PTECHLAB: Platform Technologies Laboratory
content:
PTECHLAB - Platform Technologies Laboratory is a 1-unit laboratory course with 3 contact hours per week . It requires IPATLAB1 as a prerequisite . The course complements the lecture component by covering the practical aspects of operating systems, computer architecture, and organization.

**Weekly Course Content:**
* **OS & Architecture Review (Weeks 2-4):** Practical review of Operating System types and Computer Architecture (Processor and RAM) .
* **Binary & Logic Operations (Weeks 5-8):** Performing binary addition and multiplication, and converting binary terms using logic gates and Boolean Algebra .
* **Scheduling Algorithms (Weeks 10-12):** Tracing and simulation of Non-Preemptive (FCFS, SJF, Priority) and Pre-emptive (SRTF, Round Robin, Multi-Level Queue) scheduling algorithms .
* **Assembly Language (Week 13):** Demonstration and understanding of basic assembly language commands, variables, operations, and control flows .
* **System Organization (Weeks 14-15):** Comparing Operating System types and Computer system units, including Enterprise Software and Middleware configuration .
* **Hardware & Firmware (Weeks 16-17):** Reviewing current hardware/software prices, firmware storage options, digital logic systems, and benchmarking costs/benefits .

**Assessment:**
Grading is determined by Performance Tasks (45%), Term Assessments (30%), and Written Work (25%).

source: OBTL Plan - Data Structure and Algorithm (Lecture)
topic: DSALGLEC: Data Structure and Algorithm (Lecture)
content:
DSALGLEC - Data Structure and Algorithm (Lecture) is a 2-unit lecture course involving 2 contact hours per week . It requires IPROGLEC as a prerequisite and serves as a prerequisite for MICROBOT . The course explores abstract data types (ADTs) and the implementation of fundamental data structures, including arrays, stacks, queues, linked lists, and mapping trees. It also covers internal and external searching and sorting algorithms and dynamic storage management .

**Weekly Course Content:**
* **Fundamentals (Weeks 1-2):** Introduction to Data Structures, Abstract Data Types, and the difference between static and dynamic implementations .
* **Linear Data Structures (Weeks 3-5):** In-depth study of Arrays (Linear, Multi-Dimensional, Dynamic) and Linked Lists (Singly, Doubly, Circular) .
* **Recursion (Week 6):** Recursive definitions, writing recursive programs, and analyzing efficiency .
* **Stacks and Queues (Weeks 7-11):** Representation, operations, and applications of Stacks and Queues .
* **Trees (Weeks 12-13):** Binary Trees, Tree Representation, Tree Traversals, and Expression Trees .
* **Sorting Algorithms (Weeks 14-15):** Analysis of various sorting techniques including Exchange, Selection, Insertion, Merge, and Radix Sorts .
* **Graphs (Weeks 16-17):** Directed and Undirected Graphs, Graph Representations, Search Algorithms, Shortest Path Problems, and Spanning Trees .

**Assessment:**
Course assessment relies on Performance Tasks (45%), Term Assessments (30%), and Written Work (25%). The primary programming language referenced for implementation concepts is C++.
